de.esoco.storage

Interface StorageMapping<T,A extends org.obrel.core.Relatable,C extends StorageMapping<?,A,?>>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    org.obrel.core.Relatable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractStorageMapping, ClassMapping

    public interface StorageMapping<T,A extends org.obrel.core.Relatable,C extends StorageMapping<?,A,?>>
extends org.obrel.core.Relatable
    Interface that defines the methods for a specific mapping from an object type to it's storage representation. Only a single mapping instance can exist for a certain type. All information that is specific to a particular storage implementation (e.g. like SQL column or table names) must be set as relations on the mapping or on the attributes. It is recommended that a relation of the type StorageRelationTypes.STORAGE_NAME on a mapping instance is always set.

    The generic type parameters define the types of the mapped type (T), the attribute descriptors (A) and of referenced child mappings (C). The attribute descriptors are required to be relatable objects so that relations with storage-specific metadata (e.g. JdbcRelationTypes.SQL_NAME) can be set on them. Again it is recommended that at least a relation containing the storage name exists on attribute descriptors. Attributes may also have a relation of type StorageRelationTypes.STORAGE_DATATYPE that contains the datatype to be used for storage operations, especially for the method Storage.initObjectStorage(StorageMapping).

    Storage mappings must extend the class RelatedObject to provide the functionality from the Relatable interface. Relations can and must be used to set meta-informations that are either valid for all storages or specific to certain storage implementations. For example, a relation of the type StorageRelationTypes.STORAGE_NAME on the mapping instance defines the storage name of objects described by the mapping while a relation of the type JdbcRelationTypes.SQL_NAME would override it and define their name in SQL statements.

    Implementations of storage objects and/or their mapping may implement support for the tracking of attribute modifications to allow storage implementations to optimize access to the storage back-end. To do so it must set the flag relation MetaTypes.MODIFIED to TRUE on objects when they have been modified. Storages will then automatically reset this flag to FALSE after the object modifications have been made persistent. But the flag will only be evaluated if it exists, otherwise objects will always be stored to support objects without modification tracking. Therefore implementations that track attribute changes must also set the flag to FALSE on new objects to make the storage framework recognize the modification tracking support.

    The attributes of an object with a modification flag that is set to FALSE will not be stored during a database update. But the flags of all children of the object will still be evaluated recursively, thus storing only modified objects in a hierarchy of object.

    All collections returned by this interface must not be modified by storage implementations and may therefore be returned as unmodifiable collections if the implementation prefers to do so.

      • checkAttributeValue

        java.lang.Object checkAttributeValue(A rAttribute,
                                     java.lang.Object rValue)
                              throws StorageException
        Checks whether a certain attribute value is valid for the attribute datatype and performs the necessary conversions if possible.
        Parameters:
        rAttribute - The attribute descriptor
        rValue - The attribute value to be checked (may be NULL)
        Returns:
        The attribute value, converted if necessary
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given value is invalid for the attribute
        StorageException - If accessing storage data for a conversion fails

      • createObject

        T createObject(java.util.List<?> rAttributeValues,
               boolean bAsChild)
        throws StorageException
        This method must be implemented to return a new instance of the type that is described by this mapping. The argument is a list of the attribute values to be set in the new object. The list order will be the same in which the attribute descriptors are returned by getAttributes(). The list may be empty but must never be NULL.
        Parameters:
        rAttributeValues - A list containing the attribute values
        bAsChild - TRUE if the object is read as a child of another object by the storage
        Returns:
        A new instance of the type described by this mapping, initialized with the given attribute values
        Throws:
        StorageException - If creating the object fails

      • getDefaultCriteria

        default de.esoco.lib.expression.Predicate<T> getDefaultCriteria(java.lang.Class<? extends T> rType)
        Returns a predicate with default criteria for the mapped type or a subclass of it. Can be implemented by subclasses to implement a hierarchy of persisted classes that share the same storage area (e.g. a SQL table) or to filter certain data (e.g. legacy or historical data) from queries.

        The default implementation always returns NULL which is ignored.

        Parameters:
        rType - The (sub-type) that is actually queried
        Returns:
        The default criteria for the given type or NULL for none

        Returns:

      • mapValue

        java.lang.Object mapValue(A rAttribute,
                          java.lang.Object rValue)
                   throws StorageException
        This method performs a mapping of attribute values which cannot be stored directly by a storage implementation (e.g. JDBC-based storages). The returned value must be an object that is more suitable for being persisted in such storages (like an identifier string instead of a complete entity). If no mapping is necessary or possible the argument should be returned unchanged. NULL values are allowed and should simply be returned too.

        The first argument contains the attribute descriptor for the given value. It can be used to perform attribute-specific mappings, e.g. if the result depends on the value of another attribute or the attribute type.

        Parameters:
        rAttribute - The descriptor of the attribute to map
        rValue - The value to be mapped (may be NULL)
        Returns:
        The mapped value
        Throws:
        StorageException - Implementations may throw an storage exception if they cannot map a value or need to perform other storage operations for the mapping

      • setAttributeValue

        void setAttributeValue(T rObject,
                       A rAttribute,
                       java.lang.Object rValue)
        Sets the value of a certain attribute on the given object.
        Parameters:
        rObject - The object to set the value on
        rAttribute - The descriptor of the attribute to be set
        rValue - The attribute value

      • setChildren

        void setChildren(T rObject,
                 java.util.List<?> rChildren,
                 C rChildMapping)
        Sets the children of a parent to a list of child elements. The given list MUST be used directly by the implementation because it may be a special object that implements storage access or similar.
        Parameters:
        rObject - The parent object to set the children of
        rChildren - The list of child elements
        rChildMapping - The mapping that describes the child type

      • storeReference

        void storeReference(org.obrel.core.Relatable rSourceObject,
                    T rReferencedObject)
             throws StorageException
        May be invoked by a storage implementation to store a modified object of this mapping that is referenced by another object before that object is stored.
        Parameters:
        rSourceObject - The object from which the reference originates
        rReferencedObject - The referenced object to store
        Throws:
        StorageException - If storing the reference fails
